docs.title: What is Finlite?
docs.text: Finlite is a modern, local-first personal finance application built with Clean Architecture principles and double-entry bookkeeping. It provides a powerful CLI for managing your finances with the precision of professional accounting software.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text: Double-Entry Accounting - Rock-solid financial tracking with balanced transactions Clean Architecture - Maintainable, testable, and extensible codebase Event-Driven - Domain events for audit trails and observability Structured Logging - Production-ready logging with JSON output Multi-Currency - Support for multiple currencies (USD, BRL, EUR, etc.) Local-First - Your data stays on your machine (SQLite database) Type-Safe - Full type checking with mypy Well-Tested - 187 tests (163 unit + 24 integration)

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get up and running in 3 minutes:

Installation
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/lgili/finapp.git
cd finapp/backend

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate

# Install package
pip install -e .

# Initialize database
fin init-db
Create Your First Account
fin accounts create --code "CASH" --name "Cash" --type ASSET
Record Your First Transaction
fin transactions create --description "Initial balance"
# Posting 1: CASH, 1000
# Posting 2: EQUITY, -1000

Goal: Automate transaction entry from bank statements

Technical Details: - ImportBatch entity with SHA256 hash for deduplication - StatementEntry entity with external ID - Fuzzy matching for reconciliation (date ±3 days, amount ±1%) - Configuration for column mapping (YAML)

Success Criteria: - Import 100+ transactions from Nubank CSV - Zero duplicates on re-import - 95%+ automatic reconciliation rate

Example Rule: 

- name: "Groceries at Whole Foods"
  conditions:
    - payee_matches: "(?i)whole foods"
  actions:
    - set_account: "GROCERIES"
    - add_tag: "food"

Success Criteria: - 90%+ of transactions auto-classified - Zero false positives with dry-run - Sub-second rule application on 1000 transactions

Success Criteria: - 80%+ accuracy on test set - No suggestions below confidence threshold - Outlier detection finds anomalies (duplicate charges, unusual amounts)

docs.title: API: Domain Events
docs.text:
Domain events are immutable facts emitted by use cases.

Common events:

  • AccountCreated — when an account is created
  • TransactionRecorded — when a transaction is successfully saved

Events are published to the Event Bus and handled asynchronously (or synchronously in memory). Handlers implement auditing, metrics, and side effects.

docs.title: API: Repositories
docs.text:
Repository interfaces abstract persistence details.

Common interfaces:

  • IAccountRepository — find/save accounts
  • ITransactionRepository — persist transactions and query by filters
  • IImportBatchRepository — track import batches and dedupe

Implementations (SQLAlchemy) live in infrastructure/persistence/ and are tested by integration tests.

docs.title: API: Use Cases
docs.text: This page documents the public Use Cases exposed by the application layer. Use Cases are callable from CLI, API or TUI adapters.

docs.title: Notable Use Cases

  • RecordTransactionUseCase — record a balanced transaction
  • ImportStatementUseCase — import bank statements

Use Cases accept domain DTOs and return domain entities or results. They should be covered by unit tests.

docs.title: Clean Architecture
docs.text: Finlite follows Clean Architecture to keep business logic independent from frameworks and infrastructure.

docs.title: Principles
docs.text:
• Dependency rule: inner layers do not depend on outer layers
  • Use Cases orchestrate domain logic
  • Infrastructure implements interfaces defined by the domain/application

Read the overview for diagrams: Architecture Overview.

docs.title: How we apply it
docs.text:
• Domain layer: entities, value objects, domain events
  • Application layer: use cases and DTOs
  • Infrastructure layer: repositories, event bus, logging
  • Interface layer: CLI adapters and presenters

See detailed pages for each layer: domain.md, application.md, infrastructure.md.

docs.title: Domain Layer
docs.text: The domain layer contains pure business rules: entities, value objects, domain events, and domain services.

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
• Entities: Account, Transaction, Posting
  • Value Objects: Money, AccountType
  • Domain Events: AccountCreated, TransactionRecorded

docs.title: Tests
docs.text:
Domain tests are pure unit tests and do not touch the database.

See backend/finlite/domain/ for implementation and tests/unit/domain/ for tests.

docs.title: Event Bus
docs.text: Finlite uses a publish/subscribe event bus to decouple side effects from core business logic.

docs.title: Domain Events
docs.text:
Examples:

  • AccountCreated
  • TransactionRecorded

docs.title: Handlers
docs.text:
• AuditLogHandler: writes audit entries
  • ConsoleEventHandler: development output
  • MetricsEventHandler: increments monitoring counters

Event handlers should be idempotent and resilient to errors.

docs.title: Infrastructure Layer
docs.text: The infrastructure layer implements concrete technologies: database, event bus, logging, external integrations.

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
• SQLAlchemy repositories (persistence)
  • InMemoryEventBus (development)
  • Structlog for structured logging
  • LLM adapters (optional)

Implementations must satisfy interfaces defined in domain/application layers to allow testing and swapping.

docs.title: 🖥️ Interface Layer
docs.text:
Responsibility: User interaction and external communication

Components:

  • CLI (finlite/interfaces/cli/) - Typer-based command-line interface

Dependencies: Application Layer only

Example:

@app.command()
def create(
    code: str,
    name: str,
    type: AccountType,
    currency: str = "USD",
) -> None:
    """Create a new account."""
    container = create_container()
    use_case = container.create_account_use_case()

    account = use_case.execute(
        code=code,
        name=name,
        account_type=type,
        currency=currency,
    )

    console.print(f"✅ Account {account.code} created!")

docs.title: ⚙️ Application Layer
docs.text:
Responsibility: Orchestrate business logic and coordinate operations

Components:

  • Use Cases (finlite/application/use_cases/) - Business operations
  • DTOs (finlite/application/dtos/) - Data transfer objects

Dependencies: Domain Layer, Infrastructure interfaces (not implementations)

Example:

class CreateAccountUseCase:
    def __init__(
        self,
        account_repo: IAccountRepository,
        event_bus: IEventBus,
    ):
        self._account_repo = account_repo
        self._event_bus = event_bus
        self._logger = get_logger(__name__)

    def execute(
        self,
        code: str,
        name: str,
        account_type: AccountType,
        currency: str = "USD",
    ) -> Account:
        self._logger.info("creating_account", account_code=code)

        # Check if account exists
        existing = self._account_repo.find_by_code(code)
        if existing:
            raise AccountAlreadyExistsError(code)

        # Create account entity
        account = Account.create(
            code=code,
            name=name,
            account_type=account_type,
            currency=currency,
        )

        # Persist
        self._account_repo.save(account)

        # Publish event
        event = AccountCreated(
            account_id=account.id,
            account_code=account.code,
            account_type=account.account_type,
            currency=account.currency,
        )
        self._event_bus.publish(event)

        self._logger.info("account_created", account_id=str(account.id))

        return account

docs.title: 💎 Domain Layer
docs.text:
Responsibility: Core business logic and rules

Components:

  • Entities (finlite/domain/entities/) - Business objects with identity
  • Value Objects (finlite/domain/value_objects/) - Immutable values
  • Domain Events (finlite/domain/events/) - Things that happened
  • Domain Services (finlite/domain/services/) - Business operations

Dependencies: NONE (pure business logic)

Example:

@dataclass
class Account:
    """Account entity representing a financial account."""

    id: UUID
    code: str
    name: str
    account_type: AccountType
    currency: str
    is_active: bool = True
    parent_id: UUID | None = None
    created_at: datetime = field(default_factory=datetime.utcnow)
    updated_at: datetime = field(default_factory=datetime.utcnow)

    @staticmethod
    def create(
        code: str,
        name: str,
        account_type: AccountType,
        currency: str = "USD",
        parent_id: UUID | None = None,
    ) -> "Account":
        """Factory method to create a new account."""
        return Account(
            id=uuid4(),
            code=code,
            name=name,
            account_type=account_type,
            currency=currency,
            parent_id=parent_id,
        )

    def deactivate(self) -> None:
        """Deactivate the account."""
        self.is_active = False
        self.updated_at = datetime.utcnow()

docs.title: 🔧 Infrastructure Layer
docs.text:
Responsibility: External concerns and technical details

Components:

  • Repositories (finlite/infrastructure/persistence/) - Data access
  • Event Bus (finlite/infrastructure/events/) - Event publishing
  • Logging (finlite/shared/observability/) - Structured logging

Dependencies: Domain interfaces, external libraries

Example:

class SQLAlchemyAccountRepository(IAccountRepository):
    """SQLAlchemy implementation of account repository."""

    def __init__(self, session: Session):
        self._session = session

    def save(self, account: Account) -> None:
        """Save account to database."""
        account_model = AccountModel.from_entity(account)
        self._session.add(account_model)
        self._session.commit()

    def find_by_code(self, code: str) -> Account | None:
        """Find account by code."""
        account_model = (
            self._session.query(AccountModel)
            .filter(AccountModel.code == code)
            .first()
        )
        return account_model.to_entity() if account_model else None

    def find_by_id(self, account_id: UUID) -> Account | None:
        """Find account by ID."""
        account_model = (
            self._session.query(AccountModel)
            .filter(AccountModel.id == account_id)
            .first()
        )
        return account_model.to_entity() if account_model else None

docs.title: Dependency Flow
docs.text:
The Dependency Rule: Dependencies flow inward. Outer layers depend on inner layers, never the reverse.

graph LR
    A[Interface] -->|depends on| B[Application]
    B -->|depends on| C[Domain]
    D[Infrastructure] -->|depends on| C
    B -->|uses| E[InfrastructureInterfaces]

    style C fill:#4051b5,color:#fff
    style B fill:#5c6bc0,color:#fff
    style D fill:#7986cb,color:#fff
    style A fill:#9fa8da,color:#fff
    style E fill:#7986cb,color:#fff

Key Points:

  • Domain layer has zero dependencies
  • Application layer depends on domain abstractions
  • Infrastructure implements domain interfaces
  • Interface layer depends on application layer

docs.title: Event-Driven Architecture
docs.text:
Finlite uses domain events for loose coupling and observability.

sequenceDiagram
    participant CLI
    participant UseCase
    participant EventBus
    participant AuditHandler
    participant MetricsHandler

    CLI->>UseCase: create_account(code, name, type)
    UseCase->>UseCase: Create Account entity
    UseCase->>EventBus: publish(AccountCreated)
    par Parallel handlers
        EventBus->>AuditHandler: handle(AccountCreated)
        EventBus->>MetricsHandler: handle(AccountCreated)
    end
    AuditHandler->>AuditHandler: Log audit trail
    MetricsHandler->>MetricsHandler: Increment counter
    UseCase-->>CLI: Account created

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text: ✅ Decoupled: Handlers don't know about each other ✅ Extensible: Add new handlers without modifying use cases ✅ Auditable: Full event history for compliance ✅ Observable: Metrics and logging via events

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Get Finlite running on your machine in just a few minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing Finlite, ensure you have:

  • Python 3.11 or higher (Download Python)
  • Git (Download Git)
  • pip (comes with Python)

Check your Python version

python --version
# Should show Python 3.11.x or higher

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/lgili/finapp.git
cd finapp/backend

docs.title: 2. Create Virtual Environment
docs.text:
macOS/LinuxWindowsWindows (PowerShell) 
python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate

python -m venv .venv
.venv\Scripts\activate

python -m venv .venv
.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

Virtual environment activated

Your prompt should now show (.venv) at the beginning.

docs.title: 3. Install Finlite
docs.text:
pip install -e .

This installs Finlite in editable mode with all dependencies.

docs.title: 4. Initialize Database
docs.text:
fin init-db

This creates the SQLite database at ~/.finlite/finlite.db (or location specified in .env).

docs.title: 5. Verify Installation
docs.text:
fin --version
fin --help

You should see the Finlite CLI help message with available commands.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Finlite uses environment variables for configuration. Create a .env file:

backend/.env
# Database location (default: ~/.finlite/finlite.db)
FINLITE_DATA_DIR=~/.finlite

# Default currency (default: USD)
DEFAULT_CURRENCY=USD

# Log level (default: INFO)
LOG_LEVEL=INFO

Optional Configuration

The .env file is optional. Finlite works with sensible defaults.

docs.title: Development Installation
docs.text:
If you want to contribute or run tests:

# Install with development dependencies
pip install -e ".[dev]"

# Run tests
pytest tests/

# Run type checker
mypy backend/finlite

# Run linter
ruff check .

# Format code
ruff format .

docs.title: Python Version Error
docs.text:
ERROR: This package requires Python 3.11 or higher

Solution: Install Python 3.11+ from python.org

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
ERROR: Could not install packages due to an EnvironmentError: [Errno 13] Permission denied

Solution: Use a virtual environment (recommended) or add --user flag:

pip install --user -e .

docs.title: Database Locked
docs.text:
sqlite3.OperationalError: database is locked

Solution: Close other Finlite instances and try again. SQLite doesn't support concurrent writes.

docs.title: Module Not Found
docs.text:
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'finlite'

Solution: Ensure you're in the virtual environment and installed with -e .:

source .venv/bin/activate  # Activate venv
pip install -e .            # Install package

docs.title: Updating Finlite
docs.text:
To update to the latest version:

cd finapp
git pull origin main
cd backend
pip install -e .  # Reinstall dependencies

docs.title: Uninstallation
docs.text:
To remove Finlite:

pip uninstall finlite
rm -rf ~/.finlite  # Remove database and config (optional)

docs.title: fin accounts create
docs.text:
Create a new account.

Syntax: 

fin accounts create --code CODE --name NAME --type TYPE [--currency CURRENCY] [--parent PARENT]

Options:

Option Short Required Description Default --code -c ✅ Unique account code/identifier - --name -n ✅ Account name - --type -t ✅ Account type (ASSET, LIABILITY, EQUITY, INCOME, EXPENSE) - --currency - ❌ Currency code (USD, BRL, EUR, etc.) USD --parent - ❌ Parent account code for hierarchical accounts -

Examples:

# Create basic account
fin accounts create --code "CASH" --name "Cash" --type ASSET

# Create with custom currency
fin accounts create -c "SAVINGS-BRL" -n "Brazilian Savings" -t ASSET --currency BRL

# Create hierarchical account
fin accounts create -c "GROCERIES" -n "Groceries" -t EXPENSE --parent "FOOD"

docs.title: Transactions Commands
docs.text: Record and manage financial transactions.

docs.title: fin transactions create
docs.text:
Create a new transaction (interactive mode).

Syntax: 

fin transactions create --description DESCRIPTION [--date DATE] [--payee PAYEE]

Options:

Option Short Required Description Default --description -d ✅ Transaction description - --date - ❌ Transaction date (YYYY-MM-DD) Today --payee -p ❌ Payee/vendor name -

Interactive Prompts:

After providing the basic info, you'll be prompted for postings:

  1. Account code: The account to debit/credit
  2. Amount: Positive for debit, negative for credit
  3. Repeat until you press Enter without entering an account

Examples:

# Simple transaction
fin transactions create -d "Salary payment"
# Posting 1 - Account code: CHECKING
# Posting 1 - Amount: 3000
# Posting 2 - Account code: SALARY
# Posting 2 - Amount: -3000

# With payee
fin transactions create -d "Grocery shopping" -p "Whole Foods"
# Posting 1 - Account code: GROCERIES
# Posting 1 - Amount: 150
# Posting 2 - Account code: CASH
# Posting 2 - Amount: -150

# With custom date
fin transactions create -d "Rent" --date 2025-10-01
# Posting 1 - Account code: RENT
# Posting 1 - Amount: 1200
# Posting 2 - Account code: CHECKING
# Posting 2 - Amount: -1200

   Description: Salary payment
   Date: 2025-10-12

Validation: - ✅ Minimum 2 postings required - ✅ Transaction must balance (sum = 0) - ✅ All accounts must exist

docs.title: Batch Account Creation
docs.text:
Use a script to create multiple accounts:

#!/bin/bash
accounts=(
  "CASH:Cash:ASSET"
  "CHECKING:Checking:ASSET"
  "SAVINGS:Savings:ASSET"
  "SALARY:Salary:INCOME"
  "GROCERIES:Groceries:EXPENSE"
)

for account in "${accounts[@]}"; do
  IFS=: read -r code name type <<< "$account"
  fin accounts create -c "$code" -n "$name" -t "$type"
done

docs.title: Double-Entry Accounting
docs.text: A comprehensive guide to understanding double-entry bookkeeping in Finlite.

docs.title: What is Double-Entry Accounting?
docs.text: Double-entry accounting is a system where every transaction affects at least two accounts and always balances to zero. This creates a self-checking system that prevents errors and provides a complete financial picture.

docs.title: The Golden Rule
docs.text:
The Fundamental Equation

Assets = Liabilities + Equity

And: Income - Expenses = Change in Equity

docs.title: 1. 💰 Assets (ASSET)
docs.text:
What: Things you own that have value

Normal Balance: Debit (positive)

Examples: - Cash - Bank accounts (checking, savings) - Investments - Property - Equipment

Increases: Debit (+) Decreases: Credit (-)

docs.title: 2. 📄 Liabilities (LIABILITY)
docs.text:
What: Money you owe to others

Normal Balance: Credit (negative)

Examples: - Credit cards - Loans - Mortgages - Accounts payable

Increases: Credit (-) Decreases: Debit (+)

docs.title: 3. 🏦 Equity (EQUITY)
docs.text:
What: Your net worth (Assets - Liabilities)

Normal Balance: Credit (negative)

Examples: - Opening balance - Retained earnings - Owner's equity - Capital contributions

Increases: Credit (-) Decreases: Debit (+)

docs.title: 4. 💵 Income (INCOME)
docs.text:
What: Money coming in

Normal Balance: Credit (negative)

Examples: - Salary - Dividends - Interest income - Sales revenue - Rental income

Increases: Credit (-) Decreases: Debit (+)

docs.title: 5. 💸 Expenses (EXPENSE)
docs.text:
What: Money going out

Normal Balance: Debit (positive)

Examples: - Rent - Groceries - Utilities - Transport - Insurance - Entertainment

Increases: Debit (+) Decreases: Credit (-)

docs.title: Debit vs Credit: The Easy Way
docs.text:
Forget the confusing bank terminology! In accounting:

Debit (+)Credit (-)

Increases:

  • ✅ Assets (Cash goes up)
  • ✅ Expenses (You spent money)

Decreases:

  • ❌ Liabilities (Paid off debt)
  • ❌ Equity (Withdrew money)
  • ❌ Income (Refund/correction)

Increases:

  • ✅ Liabilities (Borrowed money)
  • ✅ Equity (Added capital)
  • ✅ Income (Earned money)

Decreases:

  • ❌ Assets (Cash goes down)
  • ❌ Expenses (Refund/correction)

docs.title: Example 1: Opening Balance
docs.text:
You start with $5,000 in your checking account.

Transaction: "Opening balance"
─────────────────────────────────
CHECKING (Asset)     +5000  ← Money in
EQUITY              -5000  ← Your net worth
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

Why it works: - Assets increased by $5,000 - Equity increased by $5,000 - Assets = Equity ✓

docs.title: Example 2: Receive Salary
docs.text:
You receive your $3,000 salary.

Transaction: "Monthly salary"
─────────────────────────────────
CHECKING (Asset)     +3000  ← Bank account increases
SALARY (Income)      -3000  ← Income earned
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

Why it works: - Assets increased (you have more cash) - Income increased (credit means income up) - Your equity increased by $3,000

docs.title: Example 3: Pay Rent
docs.text:
You pay $1,200 for rent.

Transaction: "Monthly rent"
─────────────────────────────────
RENT (Expense)       +1200  ← You spent money
CHECKING (Asset)     -1200  ← Bank account decreases
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

Why it works: - Expenses increased (you spent money) - Assets decreased (less cash) - Your equity decreased by $1,200

docs.title: Example 4: Grocery Shopping
docs.text:
You buy $150 worth of groceries with cash.

Transaction: "Weekly groceries"
─────────────────────────────────
GROCERIES (Expense)   +150  ← You spent money
CASH (Asset)          -150  ← Cash decreases
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

docs.title: Example 5: Transfer Between Accounts
docs.text:
You move $500 from checking to savings.

Transaction: "Transfer to savings"
─────────────────────────────────
SAVINGS (Asset)       +500  ← Savings increases
CHECKING (Asset)      -500  ← Checking decreases
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

Why it works: - Both are assets - Total assets unchanged (just moved)

docs.title: Example 6: Buy with Credit Card
docs.text:
You buy $200 of clothes with your credit card.

Transaction: "Clothes shopping"
─────────────────────────────────
SHOPPING (Expense)    +200  ← You spent money
CREDITCARD (Liability) -200  ← Debt increased
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

Why it works: - Expenses increased (you bought something) - Liabilities increased (credit means liability up) - Your equity decreased by $200

docs.title: Example 7: Pay Off Credit Card
docs.text:
You pay $200 from your checking account to your credit card.

Transaction: "Credit card payment"
─────────────────────────────────
CREDITCARD (Liability) +200  ← Debt decreases
CHECKING (Asset)       -200  ← Cash decreases
─────────────────────────────────
Total:                   0  ✓ Balanced

Why it works: - Liabilities decreased (debit means liability down) - Assets decreased (less cash) - Your equity unchanged (just reshuffled)

docs.text: Transaction Debit Credit Salary received CHECKING (+) SALARY (-) Dividend received CHECKING (+) DIVIDENDS (-) Interest earned SAVINGS (+) INTEREST (-) Freelance payment CHECKING (+) FREELANCE (-)

docs.title: Starting Position
docs.text:
Assets = Liabilities + Equity
$5,000 = $0 + $5,000

docs.title: After Receiving Salary (+$3,000)
docs.text:
Assets = Liabilities + Equity + Income
$8,000 = $0 + $5,000 + $3,000

docs.title: After Paying Rent (-$1,200)
docs.text:
Assets = Liabilities + Equity + Income - Expenses
$6,800 = $0 + $5,000 + $3,000 - $1,200

docs.title: Simplified
docs.text:
Assets = Liabilities + Equity
$6,800 = $0 + $6,800

Your net worth increased by $1,800 (Income - Expenses).

docs.title: 1. Self-Checking ✓
docs.text:
Every transaction must balance. If it doesn't, you know there's an error.

# This will fail validation
CHECKING: +1000
SALARY: -500
# Error: Doesn't balance! Total: 500

docs.title: 2. Complete Picture 📊
docs.text: You always know: - Where money came from (credit side) - Where money went to (debit side)

docs.title: 3. Financial Statements 📈
docs.text: From your transactions, you can generate: - Balance Sheet: Assets, Liabilities, Equity at a point in time - Income Statement: Income and Expenses over a period - Cash Flow: How cash moved

docs.title: 4. Audit Trail 🔍
docs.text: Every transaction is recorded with: - Description - Date - All affected accounts - Amounts

docs.title: Mistake 1: Wrong Signs
docs.text:
❌ Wrong: 

# Receiving salary
CHECKING: -3000  # Wrong sign!
SALARY: +3000    # Wrong sign!

✅ Correct: 

# Receiving salary
CHECKING: +3000  # Asset increases
SALARY: -3000    # Income increases (credit)

docs.title: Mistake 2: Single-Entry
docs.text:
❌ Wrong: 

# Missing the other side
GROCERIES: +150
# Where did the money come from?

✅ Correct: 

GROCERIES: +150
CASH: -150

docs.title: Mistake 3: Unbalanced
docs.text:
❌ Wrong: 

RENT: +1200
CHECKING: -1000
# Total: 200 (doesn't balance!)

✅ Correct: 

RENT: +1200
CHECKING: -1200
# Total: 0 ✓

docs.title: Complete Monthly Cycle
docs.text:
# 1. Opening balance
fin transactions create -d "Opening balance"
# CHECKING: +5000, EQUITY: -5000

# 2. Receive salary
fin transactions create -d "Salary - October"
# CHECKING: +3000, SALARY: -3000

# 3. Pay rent
fin transactions create -d "Rent - October"
# RENT: +1200, CHECKING: -1200

# 4. Groceries (4 times)
fin transactions create -d "Groceries - Week 1"
# GROCERIES: +150, CHECKING: -150

fin transactions create -d "Groceries - Week 2"
# GROCERIES: +150, CHECKING: -150

fin transactions create -d "Groceries - Week 3"
# GROCERIES: +150, CHECKING: -150

fin transactions create -d "Groceries - Week 4"
# GROCERIES: +150, CHECKING: -150

# 5. Transport
fin transactions create -d "Gas"
# TRANSPORT: +100, CHECKING: -100

# 6. Utilities
fin transactions create -d "Electric bill"
# UTILITIES: +80, CHECKING: -80

# 7. Transfer to savings
fin transactions create -d "Monthly savings"
# SAVINGS: +500, CHECKING: -500

# Check final balances
fin accounts balance CHECKING   # 5670
fin accounts balance SAVINGS    # 500
fin accounts balance GROCERIES  # 600

docs.title: Sign Convention in Finlite
docs.text: Account Type Increase Decrease ASSET + (Debit) - (Credit) LIABILITY - (Credit) + (Debit) EQUITY - (Credit) + (Debit) INCOME - (Credit) + (Debit) EXPENSE + (Debit) - (Credit)

docs.title: Remember
docs.text:
• Debit = Positive number in Finlite
  • Credit = Negative number in Finlite
  • Every transaction sums to zero
  • Minimum 2 postings per transaction

docs.title: Logging & Debugging
docs.text: Finlite uses structured logging (structlog). This page explains logging modes and how to interpret logs.

docs.title: CLI Flags
docs.text:

  • --json-logs — JSON structured logs for aggregation

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Debug (human-readable):

fin --debug accounts create -c TEST -n Test -t ASSET
# 2025-10-12T14:30:00 [info] creating_account account_code=TEST

JSON mode:

fin --json-logs transactions list
# {"event":"transactions_listed","level":"info","timestamp":"...","count":10}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Increase verbosity with --debug to inspect internal steps
  • Use --json-logs when piping logs to aggregation tools

For advanced observability, refer to docs/architecture/event-bus.md (event audit traces).

docs.title: Transactions
docs.text: Transactions in Finlite record financial events using double-entry bookkeeping. Each transaction must have at least two postings and sum to zero.

docs.title: Create Transaction (interactive)
docs.text:
fin transactions create --description "Salary" --date 2025-10-01

Follow prompts to add postings (account code + amount).

docs.title: List Transactions
docs.text: fin transactions list --account CHECKING --start 2025-10-01 --end 2025-10-31

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use clear descriptions and --payee where applicable
  • Ensure transactions balance before confirming
  • Use splitting for transactions that hit multiple categories

See: Double-Entry Guide and CLI Reference.
